title: [api tooling] Abilility to filter API usage/compatibility problems
desc: When performing an API usage scan, clients will need the ability to filter the result. For example, a consumer may need the ability to say that an illegal reference/use should be ignored/filtered.  This "filtering" information needs to be stored with a component's API description, so it can be re-used on later scans.  The API tooling model needs support for this. As well, we need to be able to create/edit filters in the IDE.

title: [api tooling] Create problem category and specialized marker types
desc: Currently we have one problem marker for all API problems. We should contribute a markerTypeCategory (API Problems) to the markerSupport extension point. We should have different markers for different kinds of problems:  * Binary Compatibility * API Usage * Version Numbering

title: [api tooling] workspace api descriptions must be reusable
desc: Currently whenever our tooling builder is invoked we create a new workspace api description. This is not good as we cycle a lot of memory (depending on your workspace size), and do alot more work than is needed. Also it makes incremental updates to the api description impossible (since the descriptions' life-cycle is not long enough to ever get a notification).   Instead, for the sake of memory/performance/updatability we should create one from persisted cache/or new if no cache exists. That way we can incrementally update plugin project descriptions based on model and java element changes (PDE model, classpath, javadoc tag edits).

title: [api tooling] plugin project components need to update on PDE changes
desc: The fix to 213376 has the workspace profile updating its components based on java model and resource deltas. One piece that is missing is that a plugin project api component needs to update if there are pde model changes to it.  For example if we change exported packages to be private, we need that to be reflected in the plugins' api description.

title: [api tooling] IApiElementDescription has extraneous attributes
desc: An IApiElementDescription has an IElementDescriptor and a component name. However, the description is really just visiblity and usage restrictions. When a client resolves a description, they pass in the element and component name, so it seems pointless to pass them back.  Refactored IApiElementDescription, removing getElement() and getComponent(). The only thing that really used them was the tests and the visitors (but we can pass the element and component as args to the visitors).  Refactored ApiComponentVisitor to accept element and component name as arguments in visit methods.

title: [api tooling] remove getChildren(..) method from IApiComponentDescription
desc: The #getChildren(...) method in IApiDescription is used only by the tag scanner (that updates javadoc tags based on component.xml). The same result can be acheived by using a visitor to collect/process children.  Removed the API method and modified ComponentXMLProcessor to use visitor to collect members.

title: [api tooling] @noextend does not work for non-primitive method signatures
desc: I added a @noextend tag to DebugElement.getAdapter(Class). Subclasses that override the method were not flagged with errors. The problem is that method signatures in the API description are unqualified (since we generate from source without resolving). For example the .api_description file contained this entry:  <type name="DebugElement">   <method extend="false" name="fireSuspendEvent" signature="(I)V"/>   <method extend="false" name="getAdapter" signature="(QClass;)QObject;"/> </type>  Errors for overriding fireSuspendEvent(...) were found, as the primitive signatures are resolved by definition.

title: [api tooling] add prereq and dependent components to profile API

title: [api tooling] search more selectively for API usage problems
desc: The builder for API usage problems previoulsy extracted all reference information from a component, then resolved all references to determine if there were any usage problems.  I modified the process to first collect all API restrictions in prerequisite components and then search for references to those specific elements/conditions. This appears to speed up the search, and will allow us to add support for @noreference into the builder.

title: [api tooling] reference tracker should compute the line number for locals using the initialization line of the local

title: [api tooling] potential NPE in tool builder
desc: In the buildDelta method of our tool builder we use ToolFactory to create a class file reader, which can return null if the type passed to it is not a valid .class file. This case can occur when you move a type from one package to another.  for example:  project P1 has two packages p1 and p2, where p1 contains type t1. drag t1 out of p1 and into p2.   It turns out that (in the above example) our types to inspect contains the old classfile (P1\bin\p1\t1.class) and the new one (P1\bin\p2\t1.class). Causing an NPE when we try to get the classfile reader and use it (for the old class file), as the old classfile is no longer valid.  There are two things we could do here:  1. guard against the NPE and do no work for invalid class files 2. beef up the checking and don't ever add the invalid classfile to the listing of ones to check  any other thoughts Olivier?

title: [api tooling] Extensible javadoc tags for restrictions

For staters the extension point would be declarative:  - tag name (eg. @noimplement) - tag comment (eg. clients are not intended to implement this interface) - restriction flag (eg. bit mask for restriction from RestrictionModifiers class) - targes (eg. list of targets the tag is applicable to - class, interface, method, field, enum).  It looks like all restriction modifiers (bit mask constants) still need to be defined in code, but this will allow for a variable mapping to the modifiers, allowing for different tags to be used for the same underlying function.

desc: Currently an API component description only cares about packages and types. This needs to be extended to include methods and fields since javadoc tags (for visibility and restrictions) can be contributed to methods and fields.

desc: Checking out org.eclipse.debug.core plug-in from HEAD and setting up API tooling, using a raw 3.3 baseline (i.e. no api descriptions), I get errors like:  incompatible change: Added a method in an interface that is intended to be implemented	ILaunchConfiguration.java	org.eclipse.debug.core/core/org/eclipse/debug/core	line 61	Binary Compatibility Problem13  However, in my workspace, the source for ILaunchConfiguration has a @noimplement tag on it. title: [api tooling] API javadoc tags should support comment per element type
desc: It would be useful to allow for different tag comments for different element types. For example, for the "@noreference" tag, comments like "This class is not intended to be referenced by clients" or "This field..." would be better.  I would suggest to have a "tagcomment" that applies to all element types, but allow a comment to be specified with the "javatype" elment, to override/specialize the general comment. title: [api tooling] completion proposals all hagged up

For example, after '@' is typed and we are viewing proposals (for a class), if you start typing 'noe' the choices should be pruned to 'noextend', but instead you see 'noextend', 'noreference', 'noinstantiate'. You also see all of these choices if you type '@sinc' and do a completion.  cc Dani, as he might have some insight into why this is happening...

title: [api tooling] workspace/project settings for API warnings
desc: We need:  * a workspace preference page for setting error/warning levels for API Usage and Binary Compatibility problem * a project properties page to allow to override the settings on a per project basis * An API to retrieve/set the error/warning level for specific error kinds (so the builder can create appropriate markers)

title: [api tooling] consolidate API tooling setup
desc: We should streamline the user actions required to setup API tooling on existing plug-in projects.  To setup API tooling, the following needs to happen: * convert component.xml to javadoc source tags * delete component.xml file * add API nature to project (which updates buildspec)   This should all happen from one dialog - we can put the function into the existing "update javadoc tags" dialog. The action could be re-named to "API Tooling Setup...".  * Title/description is something like "Configure projects for API usage and binary compatibility checks" * Add checkbox for "Delete component.xml after conversion".  The operation needs to be updated to delete the component.xml file and add the API nature to the project (I don't think we need a checkbox to add the nature).  The action should only appear for PDE natured projects that do not have the API nature. F1 Help should be updated for the dialog to describe what is happening to the project. Something like:  "This dialog allows you to configure projects for API analysis. Once a project has been configured for API analysis, errors will appear in the workspace for illegal API usage and binary incompatibilities relative to a selected baseline. You can configure the default severity of API errors in your workspace on the ?? preference page. Severity settings can also be specified on a per project basis using the ?? property page."

title: [api tooling] comparator should ignore fragments and duplicate (hidden) types
desc: Binary compatibility checks should:  (1) skip fragment bundles (2) skip duplicate types (i.e. same named type in same package)  Since fragments become part of their host bundle at runtime, and all visibility/consumption of fragments is via their host, the binary compatibility check should not consider (i.e. should skip) bundles that are fragments. The compatibility is performed per host bundle (which includes all of its fragments).  A patch included on this bug report fixes up our implementation of API components to properly order combine classpath entries between hosts/fragments, and export them in their original state (i.e. jars/classes are exported to their originating host/fragment).  A package can be split between bundles (hosts and/or fragments), but if a class with the same name exists in different package fragments, the first on the class path is found at runtime. For this reason, the comparator should keep track of which classes it has visited (on a compnoent basis), and ignore duplicate types. title: [api tooling] comparator should ignore fragments and duplicate (hidden) types
desc: Binary compatibility checks should:  (1) skip fragment bundles (2) skip duplicate types (i.e. same named type in same package)  Since fragments become part of their host bundle at runtime, and all visibility/consumption of fragments is via their host, the binary compatibility check should not consider (i.e. should skip) bundles that are fragments. The compatibility is performed per host bundle (which includes all of its fragments).  A patch included on this bug report fixes up our implementation of API components to properly order combine classpath entries between hosts/fragments, and export them in their original state (i.e. jars/classes are exported to their originating host/fragment).  A package can be split between bundles (hosts and/or fragments), but if a class with the same name exists in different package fragments, the first on the class path is found at runtime. For this reason, the comparator should keep track of which classes it has visited (on a compnoent basis), and ignore duplicate types. For example, once "a.b.c.X" has been compared for a component, we should ignore any other types with the same name found in that component.

title: [api tooling] empty exported fragment when no missing classpath entry
desc: When we export a fragment, we only export class file containers that have an associated bundle classpath entry. Since a host can refer to a fragment's jars, a fragment may have no reference to its classpath containers. (This happens with the org.eclipse.ui.workbench.compatibility fragment).  I fixed up the export for fragments to also export jars that its host refers to that actually originate from the fragment.
